crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: SERVER-IIS view source via translate header
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert tcp $EXTERNAL_NET any -> $HTTP_SERVERS $HTTP_PORTS ( msg:"SERVER-IIS view source via translate header"; flow:to_server,established; http_header; content:"Translate|3A| F",fast_pattern,nocase; metadata:policy max-detect-ips drop,ruleset community; service:http; reference:bugtraq,14764; reference:bugtraq,1578; reference:cve,2000-0778; reference:nessus,10491; classtype:web-application-activity; sid:1042; rev:26; )

alert tcp $EXTERNAL_NET any -> $HOME_NET $HTTP_PORTS ( msg:"POLICY-OTHER external admin access attempt"; flow:to_server,established; http_uri; content:"/admin",fast_pattern,nocase; metadata:policy max-detect-ips drop; service:http; classtype:attempted-recon; sid:41742; rev:4; )
alert ( gid:119; sid:228; rev:2; msg:"(http_inspect) server response before client request"; metadata: rule-type preproc; classtype:unknown;)
alert ( gid:119; sid:241; rev:2; msg:"(http_inspect) Content-Transfer-Encoding used as HTTP header"; metadata: policy max-detect-ips drop, rule-type preproc; classtype:unknown;)

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET INFO EXE - Served Attached HTTP
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert http $EXTERNAL_NET any -> $HOME_NET any (msg:"ET INFO EXE - Served Attached HTTP"; flow:to_client,established; http.header; content:"Content-Disposition"; nocase; content:"attachment"; nocase; file.data; content:"MZ"; within:2; classtype:misc-activity; sid:2014520; rev:7; metadata:created_at 2012_04_06, updated_at 2022_05_03;)

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET INFO EXE IsDebuggerPresent (Used in Malware Anti-Debugging)
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert http $EXTERNAL_NET any -> $HOME_NET any (msg:"ET INFO EXE IsDebuggerPresent (Used in Malware Anti-Debugging)"; flow:established,to_client; flowbits:isset,ET.http.binary; http.header; content:!"|0d 0a|x-avast"; file.data; content:"IsDebuggerPresent"; classtype:misc-activity; sid:2015744; rev:5; metadata:created_at 2012_09_28, updated_at 2022_05_03;)

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET DNS Query to a *.top domain - Likely Hostile
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert dns $HOME_NET any -> any any (msg:"ET DNS Query to a *.top domain - Likely Hostile"; threshold:type limit, track by_src, count 1, seconds 30; dns.query; content:".top"; nocase; endswith; reference:url,www.symantec.com/connect/blogs/shady-tld-research-gdn-and-our-2016-wrap; reference:url,www.spamhaus.org/statistics/tlds/; classtype:bad-unknown; sid:2023883; rev:4; metadata:affected_product Windows_XP_Vista_7_8_10_Server_32_64_Bit, attack_target Client_Endpoint, created_at 2017_02_07, deployment Perimeter, signature_severity Major, updated_at 2020_09_15;)

alert udp $HOME_NET any -> any 53 ( msg:"INDICATOR-COMPROMISE Suspicious .top dns query"; flow:to_server; byte_test:1,!&,0xF8,2; content:"|03|top|00|",fast_pattern,nocase; metadata:policy max-detect-ips drop,policy security-ips drop; service:dns; reference:url,en.wikipedia.org/wiki/.top; classtype:misc-activity; sid:43687; rev:2; )

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: FILE-EXECUTABLE Portable Executable binary file magic detected
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert tcp $EXTERNAL_NET $FILE_DATA_PORTS -> $HOME_NET any ( msg:"FILE-EXECUTABLE Portable Executable binary file magic detected"; flow:to_client,established; file_data; content:"MZ"; byte_jump:4,58,relative,little; content:"PE|00 00|",within 4,distance -64; metadata:policy max-detect-ips drop; service:ftp-data,http,imap,pop3; classtype:policy-violation; sid:15306; rev:22; )

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: ET POLICY PE EXE or DLL Windows file download HTTP
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert http $EXTERNAL_NET any -> $HOME_NET any (msg:"ET POLICY PE EXE or DLL Windows file download HTTP"; flow:established,to_client; flowbits:isnotset,ET.http.binary; flowbits:isnotset,ET.INFO.WindowsUpdate; file_data; content:"MZ"; within:2; byte_jump:4,58,relative,little; content:"PE|00 00|"; distance:-64; within:4; flowbits:set,ET.http.binary; reference:url,doc.emergingthreats.net/bin/view/Main/2018959; classtype:policy-violation; sid:2018959; rev:4; metadata:created_at 2014_08_19, former_category POLICY, updated_at 2017_02_01;)

crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_msg: POLICY-OTHER HTTP request by IPv4 address attempt
crowdsourced_ids_results.rule_raw: alert tcp any any -> any $HTTP_PORTS ( msg:"POLICY-OTHER HTTP request by IPv4 address attempt"; flow:to_server,established; http_header; content:"Host:",fast_pattern,nocase; pcre:"/^Host\x3a\s*(?:(?:25[0-5]|2[0-4][0-9]|[01]?[0-9]?[0-9])\.){3}(?:25[0-5]|2[0-4][0-9]|[01]?[0-9]?[0-9])\s*:?\s*\d*\s*$/ims"; service:http; reference:url,www.w3.org/Protocols/rfc2616/rfc2616-sec15.html; classtype:policy-violation; sid:50447; rev:1; )

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered downloader. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Regsvr32 DLL Execution With Uncommon Extension
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects a "regsvr32" execution where the DLL doesn't contain a common file extension.

attributes.magic: Composite Document File V2 Document, Little Endian, Os: Windows, Version 10.0, Code page: 1251, Author: Gydar, Last Saved By: Gydar, Name of Creating Application: Microsoft Excel, Create Time/Date: Fri Jun  5 18:19:34 2015, Last Saved Time/Date: Thu Nov  3 13:31:09 2022, Security: 0

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects Microsoft Excel spreadsheets that contain hidden sheets. Presence of a hidden sheet alone is not indication of malicious behavior.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

exiftool.TitleOfParts: Sheet, Sheet1, Sheet2, Sheet3, Sheet4, Sheet5, Sheet6
exiftool.Author: Gydar

crowdsourced_ai_results.analysis:
The provided macro code exhibits several characteristics commonly associated with malicious behavior. 

1. Obfuscation and Complexity: The macro contains numerous obfuscated strings and complex formulas that are difficult to interpret at first glance. This is a common tactic used by malware authors to hide the true intent of their code.

2. Auto_Open() Functionality: The presence of an `Auto_Open` function indicates that the macro is designed to execute automatically when the document is opened. This is a typical method for malware to ensure it runs without user consent.

3. Suspicious Function Calls: The use of functions like `CHAR()` in combination with arithmetic operations (e.g., `CHAR(216/2)`) suggests that the macro may be constructing strings or commands dynamically, potentially leading to harmful actions.

4. Network Activity Indicators: There are multiple references to URLs within the macro, such as `['"://ftp.agir-santeinternati"`, which implies that the macro may attempt to connect to external servers. This could be for downloading additional payloads or exfiltrating data.

5. Manipulation of Excel Features: The macro includes various calls to manipulate Excel features, such as printing headers and cell values, which can be indicative of attempts to create a misleading interface or to hide malicious activities behind normal-looking spreadsheet operations.

6. Potential File System Access: The macro constructs paths that suggest it may interact with the file system, particularly with references to `System32\\` and `C:\\Windows\\`. This raises concerns about potential file manipulation or execution of unauthorized programs.

7. Data Exfiltration Risks: The presence of concatenated strings that appear to form URLs or file paths could indicate attempts to send sensitive information out of the local environment.

8. Persistence Mechanisms: Although not explicitly shown, the complexity and structure of the macro suggest that it might include mechanisms to maintain persistence on the infected machine, possibly through registry modifications or repeated executions.

Overall, the combination of automatic execution, obfuscation, suspicious network activity, and potential file system access strongly indicates that this macro is designed with malicious intent.

The macro sheet named "\u0000Sheet" contains multiple Excel 4.0 macro formulas.  These formulas utilize the `CHAR` function with arithmetic operations to generate characters.  Several cells contain concatenated strings using the `T` function, referencing the output of other cells containing `CHAR` formulas. The cells `H10`, `J10`, `L10`, `N10`, `H14`, `J14`, `L14`, and `N14` appear to contain obfuscated URLs, split into two parts within each cell. Cell `E21` concatenates characters that form part of these URLs.  Other cells build further strings seemingly related to file paths (e.g., "System32\\", ":\\Windows\\"). Cell `G13` contains multiple nested `FORMULA` calls, referencing numerous cells containing these constructed strings and characters.  The formulas, especially within `G13`, chain together the character and string fragments, constructing what appear to be URLs and commands, likely to be executed. The macro appears to leverage the `Auto_Open` function based on the cell value found in `Sheet!G3`. This suggests the macro executes automatically upon document opening.
